oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Lee Greenwood Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Lee Greenwood (performer) for the Ralph Emery Show. Recording is from June 29, 1982.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Lee Greenwood
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Lee Greenwood radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:17) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery introduction voiceover] -- (00:42) Greenwood and Emery joke about Greenwood's recent success -- (02:07) Emery invites Greenwood to describe who he is for the audience -- (04:36) "She's Lying" is discussed by Emery and reflected on as a strong single by Goldsboro -- (05:48) Emery invites Goldsboro to be the performing disc jockey for Janie Fricke's "Don't Worry About Me Baby" -- (06:56) Emery has Goldsboro discuss how he had created the same commercial as Fricke -- (07:55) Emery addresses Goldsboro prompting him to sing his McDonald's commercial -- (09:21) Goldsboro reflects on the success of "IT Turns Me Inside Out" and the number of records he recorded that were never released -- (13:03) Emery invites Goldsboro to introduce the Statler Brothers' "Whatever," and how he met them at RCA -- (13:53) Goldsboro discusses how he wrote "A Love Song" for Kenny Rodgers -- (14:17) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood outro voiceover] -- (15:41) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood introduction voiceover] -- (16:01) Greenwood reveals he is moving and emery introduces "I'll be Your Man Around the House" -- (16:41) Emery invites Greenwood to reflect on the fear following a successful release -- (18:32) Emery and Greenwood discuss how long Greenwood had been on successful on the charts -- (19:45) Emery divulges some strong words from his mother -- (20:44) Emery and Greenwood discuss the decisions made for Nashville Alive -- (22:10) Emery recalls a story about his discussion with Marty Robbins about performing with Ray Conniff -- (23:18) Greenwood reflects on working with Ricky Skaggs for the Jimmy Rodgers Festival -- (24:10) Emery invites Greenwood to reflect on his track scholarship he received -- (25:45) Greenwood reveals a new dance has been associated with "Ain't No Trick (It Takes Magic)" -- (26:54) Emery reflects on when he did not play "Folsom Prison Blues" while interviewing Bobby Bare -- (28:37) Emery recalls meeting Susie McEntire and Greenwood expresses his desire to have a brother -- (29:34) Emery inquires about the writing success of Greenwood only to be cut off -- (30:26) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood outro voiceover] -- (31:48) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood introduction voiceover] -- (32:11) Emery introduces Greenwood who introduces Waylon Jennings' "Women Know How to Carry On" -- (32:40) Emery reintroduces the question of the success that Greenwood has had as a songwriter -- (34:26) Emery reveals a speech Jimmy Davis gave -- (35:06) Emery and Greenwood discuss how Greenwood's "Thank You For Saving My Life" was written for Ronnie Milsap -- (35:57) Emery and Greenwood joke about the difficulties B-Side tapes have received -- (37:33) Emery inquires about the amount of people Greenwood has met in Nashville -- (38:49) Greenwood discusses working with the Kendalls -- (39:47) Emery inquires about Greenwood's family and moving status -- (42:33) Greenwood and Emery discuss Calamity Jane and "Walking After Midnight" -- (44:27) Emery invites Greenwood to reflect on the talent he was surrounded with, and Greenwood reveals his mother's eccentric mannerisms -- (46:38) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood outro voiceover]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Greenwood, Lee;
